After scoring the most points in the game, Jake remained humble and encouraged his teammates.
My dad always teaches me to be humble, even when I do something really great.
When I helped my neighbor, she was humble and said she appreciated my kindness.
The humble puppy wagged his tail happily, even though he was the smallest in the litter.

meanings: To make someone feel really bad or embarrassed, especially in front of other people, so that they lose their confidence.
examples: I felt humiliated when I tripped and fell during the school play in front of everyone.
It can humiliate a friend if you tease them about their mistakes during a game.
When I forgot my lines, I was worried it would humiliate me in front of my classmates.
It's not nice to humiliate someone by laughing at them when they make a mistake.
My brother tried to humiliate me by showing my silly dance moves to everyone at the party.

meanings: Impact is when something has a strong effect on you or your feelings, like how a big surprise can make you feel excited or how a compliment can make you smile.
examples: The rain had a big impact on our picnic, so we had to eat inside.
Learning to read can have a positive impact on your grades in school.
When I help my little brother with his homework, I can see the impact it has on him.
The loud noise from the game had an impact on how well I could concentrate.
Helping others can have a great impact on their happiness and make you feel good too.

meanings: To implore means to ask someone very seriously and with a lot of feeling to do something that is really important to you, like when you beg your parents to let you stay up late for a special event.
examples: I implore my mom to let me stay up late to watch my favorite movie.
When it started to rain, I implored my friends to come inside and play games.
I implored my teacher to help me with my math homework because I didn’t understand it.
My little brother implored me to play with him instead of doing my chores.
During the school assembly, I implored my classmates to be quiet so we could hear the speaker.

meanings: To make someone do something they don't want to do, like following a rule or idea that you think is important.
examples: The teacher wanted to impose a new rule about how we should line up for lunch.
My brother tried to impose his favorite game on me, but I wanted to play something else.
Sometimes parents impose chores on kids to help teach responsibility and teamwork.
At the playground, it's not nice to impose your ideas on other kids who want to play differently.
During the group project, one student tried to impose their opinion without listening to anyone else's ideas.

meanings: To make something bigger or have more of it, like when you get more friends or when your score goes up in a game.
examples: When we water the plants, their leaves start to increase in size and look healthier.
If you practice your math every day, you can increase your skills and get better grades.
Eating fruits and vegetables can help increase your energy for playing sports.
If we all work together, we can increase the number of books in our classroom library.
The more we exercise, the more we can increase our strength and run faster.

meanings: To inhale means to take a deep breath in through your nose or mouth, like when you smell your favorite food or get ready to blow up a balloon.
examples: Before diving into the pool, I inhale deeply to hold my breath underwater.
When I blow out birthday candles, I always inhale the sweet smell of the cake first.
My puppy loves to sniff flowers and inhale the fresh scent of spring.
During yoga class, we learn to inhale slowly and feel calm and relaxed.
When I see my favorite food cooking, I can't help but inhale the delicious aroma.

meanings: To put something inside something else, like when you put a photo into a photo album or slide a note into your backpack.
examples: You can insert your drawing into the folder to keep it safe.
I will insert the batteries into my new toy so it can work.
Please insert your name on the top of the paper before turning it in.
She decided to insert a sticker on her notebook to make it special.
When you play the game, you need to insert the card in the slot to start.

meanings: Instant means something that happens right away, like when you microwave food and it's hot in just a few seconds.
examples: I felt an instant rush of excitement when I saw my birthday cake.
The teacher gave us an instant quiz, and we had to answer quickly.
In an instant, the dog jumped up to catch the frisbee in the air.
When the rain started, we ran for cover in an instant to stay dry.
I found an instant snack in the cupboard when I got hungry after school.

meanings: To intend means to plan to do something, like when you decide you want to play outside after you finish your chores.
examples: I intend to practice my soccer skills every day after school.
My mom intends to bake cookies for my birthday party next week.
We intend to finish our art project by the end of the week.
I intend to read three books this month for my reading challenge.
My teacher intends to help us learn new math games this year.

meanings: The interior is the inside part of something, like the rooms inside a house or the space inside a car where people sit.
examples: The interior of the treehouse is painted bright colors and has cozy cushions to sit on.
We discovered a secret room in the interior of the old castle while on a school field trip.
My dog loves to curl up in the interior of his soft bed when he takes a nap.
The interior of my backpack has lots of pockets for books, snacks, and my favorite toys.
In art class, we learned how to draw the interior of a house, including all the rooms and furniture.

meanings: To enter a place or join a conversation when you are not invited, like walking into a friend's game without asking if you can play.
examples: It’s not nice to intrude on someone’s game without asking if you can join.
When I was reading, my little brother tried to intrude by making loud noises.
The dog would intrude into my room whenever I left the door open.
I felt sad when my friend intruded on my secret by telling everyone.
Please don’t intrude on our picnic; we want some time alone to enjoy it!

meanings: To enter a place where you are not welcome and cause problems, like when a big group of people comes into a quiet space without asking.
examples: The ants decided to invade our picnic and steal our food.
When we play outside, the bees sometimes invade our backyard to find flowers.
During the game, the other team tried to invade our area to score a goal.
One day, the frogs invaded our garden, hopping everywhere and making noise.
My little brother tries to invade my room to play with my toys when I'm not there.

meanings: To isolate means to keep someone or something alone and away from others. For example, if you choose to sit by yourself during lunch instead of with your friends, you are isolating yourself.
examples: If someone is sick, we might isolate them to keep everyone else healthy.
When I want to focus on my homework, I isolate myself in my quiet room.
The teacher asked us to isolate the important parts of the story we read.
Sometimes, animals isolate themselves when they are feeling scared or lonely.
In science class, we learned how to isolate different colors from the rainbow.

meanings: To make fun of someone in a hurtful way, like laughing at them when they trip or make a mistake.
examples: Some kids jeer at others when they miss a goal in soccer practice.
When Jake tripped on the playground, a few classmates started to jeer at him.
It’s not nice to jeer at someone just because they are different or make mistakes.
During the talent show, a few kids began to jeer when someone forgot their lines.
If you jeer at your friends, they might feel sad and not want to play with you.

meanings: Keen means being very excited and eager to do something. For example, if you are keen to go to the park, it means you really want to go and have fun there!
examples: My brother is keen to learn how to ride his bike without training wheels.
Lily is keen on painting and spends hours creating beautiful pictures.
During the science fair, I was keen to show my project about volcanoes.
My dog is keen to play fetch whenever I throw his favorite ball.
At soccer practice, my team is keen to win the championship trophy this year.

meanings: To lack something means you don't have it when you need or want it, like if you lack a snack, it means you don’t have one to eat.
examples: I felt a lack of energy after playing outside all day.
The team lost the game because they had a lack of practice.
She showed a lack of interest in the book we read together.
There was a lack of colors in my painting, so I added more.
His lack of focus made it hard for him to finish his homework.

meanings: A limb is an arm or leg that helps us move, play, and do things like jump or pick up toys.
examples: The monkey swung from limb to limb in the tall tree, looking for bananas.
When I fell while playing soccer, I landed on my arm, which is my favorite limb.
My dog wags his tail like a happy limb whenever he sees me come home.
In art class, we drew a picture of a person with long limbs and bright colors.
The bird stretched its wings, showing its strong limbs before taking off into the sky.

meanings: To walk in a way that is difficult because one of your legs or feet is hurt or doesn't work properly, like when you step on something sharp and it hurts.
examples: After he tripped on a rock, Jake had to limp back home.
The puppy hurt his paw and now he has to limp when he walks.
When Maria twisted her ankle, she had to limp during gym class.
I saw a bird with a hurt wing, and it was trying to limp to its nest.
My brother hurt his leg playing soccer, so he had to limp around the house.

meanings: Livelihood is the way a person makes money to support themselves and their family, like having a job, selling things, or doing work that helps others.
examples: My dad works hard to earn a livelihood by teaching other kids how to play soccer.
Some people sell fruits and vegetables at the market to support their families and earn a livelihood.
My mom's bakery is her livelihood because it helps her pay for our home and food.
When I grow up, I want to find a livelihood that lets me help animals and protect nature.
Artists create beautiful paintings, and for many, this is their livelihood and a way to share their talent.

meanings: To locate something means to find out where it is, like when you search for your missing book in your room.
examples: I need to locate my missing backpack before class starts.
Can you help me locate the treasure map in the backyard?
We will locate all the missing puzzle pieces on the table.
My mom asked me to locate the remote control in the living room.
In science class, we learned how to locate stars in the night sky.

meanings: A mammoth was a giant, furry animal that looked like a big elephant and lived a long time ago when the Earth was very cold, during a time called the Ice Age.
examples: The mammoth was so big that it could reach the tops of the tallest trees.
In our science class, we learned that the mammoth lived a long time ago during the Ice Age.
I saw a movie where a mammoth helped a group of friends on their adventure.
My favorite animal in the museum was the mammoth because of its huge tusks and furry body.
If I could have any pet, I would choose a friendly mammoth to go on fun walks with me!

meanings: A master is a person who is very skilled at something, like a teacher who knows a lot or a musician who plays an instrument really well.
examples: My dad is a master at fixing things around the house, like broken toys and leaky faucets.
In soccer practice, our coach is a master at teaching us new tricks and plays.
My older sister is a master painter; her art always wins first place in our school contests.
The magician at the birthday party was a master of tricks, making cards disappear right before our eyes.
I want to be a master chef when I grow up, cooking delicious meals for my family and friends.

meanings: Being mature means being grown up and responsible, like when you take care of your pets or help your friends when they need it.
examples: My brother is very mature for his age and always helps me with my homework.
The tree in our yard is mature, providing lots of shade for us to play under.
When I saw how mature my dog was, I decided to teach him a new trick.
In class, we talked about how mature plants need more water and sunlight to grow.
My dad said that being mature means making good choices, even when it’s hard.

meanings: A meadow is a sunny, open field filled with soft green grass and colorful flowers where animals like rabbits and butterflies like to roam and play.
examples: The butterflies danced above the colorful flowers in the sunny meadow.
We had a picnic on the green meadow, surrounded by tall trees and singing birds.
My dog loves to run and chase squirrels in the wide meadow near our house.
In spring, the meadow is filled with blooming wildflowers that smell so sweet.
We found a hidden meadow while exploring the woods, and it felt like a secret garden.

meanings: Melancholy is a feeling of being sad or a little lonely, like when you miss a friend or feel blue on a cloudy day.
examples: I felt a bit melancholy when my best friend moved away to another city.
The rainy weather made everyone in the class feel a little melancholy during recess.
As I looked at old photos, a sense of melancholy washed over me, remembering happy moments.
My dog seemed melancholy when I left for school without saying goodbye.
Listening to sad music sometimes makes me feel a little melancholy, even if I don’t know why.

meanings: A menace is someone or something that causes trouble or makes people feel scared, like a bully who picks on others.
examples: The storm was a menace, causing strong winds that knocked down branches everywhere.
The big dog next door seemed like a menace when it barked loudly at us.
In the game, the monster was a menace that chased us through the dark forest.
My little brother can be a menace when he spills juice on the carpet.
The weeds in the garden were a menace, taking over the flowers we planted.

meanings: Merit is when someone does something really well or has a special skill, which makes them worthy of praise or a reward.
examples: Winning the art contest showed that she had great merit for her creativity.
His hard work in school earned him merit and made his teacher very proud.
The team received a trophy because their teamwork and sportsmanship had real merit.
Helping my little brother with his homework has merit because it makes him feel confident.
The teacher said that every student's effort in class has merit, even if they make mistakes.

meanings: To migrate means to move from one place to another, like when birds fly to a warmer place in the winter or when people change homes to find a better place to live.
examples: Every spring, many birds migrate to warmer places to find food and build their nests.
Some families migrate to different cities for new jobs and better schools for their children.
When the weather gets cold, butterflies migrate to sunny locations to stay warm.
My family decided to migrate to a new house because we wanted a bigger backyard to play in.
In the fall, the geese migrate south, flying in a V shape across the sky.

meanings: A misfortune is something bad that happens that makes you feel sad or upset, like losing your favorite toy or having a bad day.
examples: When I lost my favorite toy, it felt like a big misfortune.
My dog had a misfortune when he got stuck in the fence.
During the soccer game, my teammate's misfortune made us lose the match.
It was a misfortune that it rained on our picnic day.
My brother's misfortune of breaking his skateboard made him very sad.

meanings: A misgiving is a feeling of worry or doubt you get when you're not sure if something will go well, like when you have a bad feeling before a big test or a new adventure.
examples: I felt a misgiving before the big soccer game because I wasn't sure if I was ready.
When I saw the roller coaster, a little misgiving made me think twice about going on it.
My sister had misgivings about the new puppy because she was worried it would be too much work.
I had a misgiving about asking my friend to play because I thought he might say no.
Before the school play, I felt misgivings about forgetting my lines on stage.

meanings: To make fun of someone by copying them or saying mean things, which can hurt their feelings.
examples: It’s not nice to mock someone just because they missed the basketball shot.
When my brother fell off his bike, I didn’t want to mock him, so I helped him up.
At school, we learned that it’s better to be kind than to mock others for their mistakes.
Some kids mock others for their clothes, but we should all wear what makes us happy.
I felt sad when my classmates began to mock me for my singing during music class.

meanings: Being modest means not bragging about your achievements and being happy with who you are without needing to show off. It's like when you win a game but still cheer for your friends and let them know t...
examples: She won the race, but she remained modest and said her friends helped her train.
Even though he is good at soccer, he is modest and never brags about it.
When she got an award, she gave credit to her teammates because she is modest.
His modest nature makes him a great friend because he always supports others.
After finishing the puzzle, she felt proud but was modest about her accomplishment.

meanings: To mope means to feel sad and not want to do anything fun, like when you sit alone and don't join in games with your friends.
examples: After losing the game, Sam started to mope instead of cheering up and trying again.
Lily didn’t want to play outside because she was mope after her friend moved away.
When Max couldn't find his favorite toy, he began to mope on the couch all afternoon.
It’s okay to mope sometimes, but it’s important to talk to someone when you feel sad.
When it rains, I sometimes mope inside instead of going out to play with my friends.

meanings: To snuggle up in a comfy place, like under a soft blanket or next to a friend, where you feel warm and safe.
examples: The baby bird will nestle close to its mother for warmth and safety.
After a long day, I like to nestle under my favorite blanket and read a book.
The puppy loves to nestle in my lap when I watch TV in the evening.
When it gets cold, I like to nestle by the fireplace with my family.
The little girl wanted to nestle her stuffed animals all around her while she slept.

meanings: To nourish means to give food and care that help someone or something grow strong and healthy, like how we eat good food to feel good and have energy.
examples: We need to nourish our plants with water and sunlight so they can grow tall and strong.
Eating fruits and vegetables helps nourish our bodies and gives us energy to play.
My mom always says that a good breakfast will nourish my brain for a day of learning.
When we take care of our pets, we nourish them with food, love, and attention.
Reading books can nourish our imagination and help us learn new things every day.

meanings: To observe means to watch something carefully and notice the details, like looking closely at a butterfly to see its colors and how it flies.
examples: I will observe the butterflies in the garden to see how they move from flower to flower.
During science class, we will observe the stars through a telescope tonight.
My teacher told us to observe how the plants grow in our classroom.
At the zoo, I will observe the lions as they play and rest in the sun.
When I bake cookies, I like to observe how the dough changes in the oven.

meanings: Obstinate means being really stubborn and not wanting to change your mind, even when someone else suggests a different idea. It's like refusing to eat your vegetables even though your parents say they...
examples: My little brother is obstinate and refuses to eat his vegetables, even when Mom tells him they are healthy.
During the game, Sarah was obstinate about her team winning, even when they were losing by a lot.
The dog was obstinate and wouldn't come inside, no matter how much I called him.
When it was time to clean up, my obstinate friend insisted on playing with his toys instead.
I tried to explain my idea, but my obstinate classmate wouldn't listen to anything I said.

meanings: To obtain means to get something you want or need, like when you ask for a snack and your parent gives it to you.
examples: I want to obtain a new book from the library to read this weekend.
To win the game, we need to obtain the special key hidden in the treasure chest.
My dad helped me obtain the materials I needed to build my model rocket.
I will obtain a snack from the kitchen when I finish my homework.
At the science fair, I hope to obtain a prize for my cool volcano project.

meanings: To take up space or use a place, like when you sit in a chair or play in a room.
examples: The big tree in our backyard occupies a lot of space and gives us shade on sunny days.
During art class, we occupy our desks with paints and brushes to create colorful pictures.
My little brother likes to occupy the living room with his toys while I watch TV.
The playground is a fun place where kids can occupy their time playing games and climbing.
When we read books, we occupy our minds with new stories and adventures.

meanings: An orchard is a special place where many fruit trees grow together, like apples and cherries, and you can visit to pick and eat the tasty fruits.
examples: We visited an orchard filled with apple trees and picked fresh fruit for our snack.
My family goes to the orchard every fall to gather ripe pears and make pies.
During our field trip, we learned how to plant new trees in the orchard.
The orchard near my house has a big sign that says "Welcome to the Fruit Paradise!"
In the summer, we love to have picnics in the shady spots of the orchard.

meanings: An orphan is a child who does not have a mom or dad because they have passed away, so they may need extra love and care from others.
examples: The storybook about the orphan showed how he found a new family who loved him.
In art class, we learned about famous paintings made by an orphan who became very successful.
The movie we watched was about an orphan who went on an adventure to find a home.
My teacher told us that an orphan can be adopted by a loving family and find happiness.
At the shelter, we learned that some animals feel like orphans because they need a new home.
synonyms: kid without a mom or dad

meanings: Outrage is a strong feeling of anger or shock when something unfair happens, like when you see someone being treated badly and it makes you want to help them.
examples: I felt outrage when I saw someone being mean to my friend at school.
The team's loss caused outrage among the fans, who thought they played really well.
It was an outrage when the teacher announced we would have homework over the weekend.
My parents felt outrage when they found out someone had broken our window.
I could see the outrage on my little brother's face when his toy was taken away.

meanings: Lines that are always the same distance apart and never meet, like the two sides of a straight road that go on forever.
examples: The train tracks run parallel to each other, so they never touch.
In art class, we drew parallel lines to make a cool pattern on our paper.
When we ride our bikes, we always try to stay parallel on the path.
The two roads are parallel, which helps cars drive safely without bumping into each other.
During the race, I ran parallel to my friend to keep up with her speed.

meanings: To paralyze means to make someone or something unable to move at all, like when a toy stops working and can’t play anymore.
examples: When the ice storm hit, the roads were paralyzed and no cars could drive safely.
The sudden loud noise seemed to paralyze my puppy, and he wouldn’t move for a moment.
In the game, if you get caught by the monster, it will paralyze your character for two turns.
The freezing temperatures can paralyze the water in the pond, making it safe for ice skating.
When I saw the big spider, I was so scared that it felt like I was paralyzed!

meanings: To parch means to make something very dry, like when the hot sun dries out the grass or makes your skin feel thirsty.
examples: The sun can parch the flowers if they don’t get enough water.
After a hot day outside, my skin felt parched and I needed a drink.
If we leave the bread out too long, it will parch and become hard.
The desert is a place where the sun can parch the ground, making it dry and cracked.
In summer, we must water the garden often or the plants will parch and wilt.

meanings: A passage is a part of a story or book that tells us what happens next or shares important information. It can also be a hallway that connects different rooms in a building.
examples: The book had a beautiful passage about a brave knight and his adventures.
In our school library, there is a passage that leads to the reading nook.
I found a passage in my favorite story that made me laugh out loud.
The hallway at home is a narrow passage that connects the living room to the kitchen.
During our nature walk, we discovered a hidden passage through the tall bushes.

meanings: A patriot is someone who loves their country very much and wants to help make it a good place to live for everyone.
examples: A patriot stands up for their country when it needs help or support.
During the parade, everyone cheered for the patriots who fought for our freedom.
My dad taught me that being a patriot means respecting our flag and what it represents.
When we celebrate Independence Day, we honor the patriots who helped build our nation.
Reading about famous patriots in history makes me proud to be part of my country.

meanings: A peasant is a farmer who grows food and takes care of the land, often living in a simple way with little money.
examples: The peasant worked hard in the fields to grow food for everyone in the village.
In the story, the peasant lived in a small house with his family and farm animals.
The peasant used a simple plow to help plant seeds in the rich soil.
During the festival, the peasant showed everyone how to make bread from his wheat.
My teacher told us about a peasant who became a hero in a fairytale.

meanings: A peer is a person who is about the same age as you, like a friend or someone in your class.
examples: My peer and I worked together on our science project about plants.
During gym class, I played basketball with my peers and scored a point!
At the birthday party, I enjoyed playing games with my peers and eating cake.
When I read my book, my peer sat next to me and shared his favorite stories.
In art class, my peer and I painted a big mural together on the wall.

meanings: A permit is a special paper that lets you do something, like ride your bike in a park or have a dog. It's like getting a green light to have fun!
examples: I need a permit to ride my bike in the park.
Our teacher gave us a permit to use the art room after school.
You need a permit to have a lemonade stand on the sidewalk.
My dad showed me his fishing permit before we went to the lake.
The school gave us a permit to have a field trip to the zoo.

meanings: To keep trying to do something even when it’s tough or you feel like giving up, like practicing a sport until you get better.
examples: Even when the math problems are hard, I will persist until I solve them.
My dog likes to chase the ball, and he will persist until he catches it.
During the school play, I will persist and remember my lines no matter how nervous I feel.
When building my LEGO castle, I had to persist because some pieces wouldn’t fit at first.
If I fall off my bike while learning, I will persist and try again until I can ride smoothly.

meanings: To persuade someone means to talk to them in a way that makes them want to agree with you or do something you like. For example, you might persuade a friend to try your favorite ice cream flavor by te...
examples: I tried to persuade my mom to let me have a sleepover with my friends.
My teacher used interesting facts to persuade us to take care of the environment.
Sam wanted to play outside, but I had to persuade him to finish his homework first.
I can persuade my dad to buy pizza for dinner by telling him how much I love it.
During gym class, I tried to persuade my classmates to play soccer instead of basketball.

meanings: A pessimist is a person who always thinks things will go wrong and worries about bad outcomes, instead of being hopeful and looking for the good things that can happen.
examples: My brother is such a pessimist; he thinks it will rain every time we plan a picnic.
During the game, Sarah was a pessimist and kept saying we would lose, even when we were winning.
If you are a pessimist, you might think that your team will never win the championship.
My dad is a pessimist about the weather; he always believes it will be cloudy on our beach days.
Even though I was excited about the school play, my friend acted like a pessimist and said no one would come to see it.

meanings: Petty" means something that is not very important or is about little things, like worrying about who gets to pick the game when everyone can have fun playing together.
examples: It's petty to argue over who gets to choose the game when we can all play together.
My brother got petty about sharing the last cookie, even though we could just bake more.
The teacher said it's petty to complain about a small mistake on our homework.
Instead of being petty, we should help each other when we make mistakes.
It's petty to be upset about a tiny scratch on my favorite toy when I have so many.

meanings: A phase is a step in a process where something is changing or developing, like how a caterpillar turns into a butterfly, with each stage being a different phase.
examples: My science project has several phases, like planning, building, and presenting to the class.
Every puppy goes through a playful phase before they learn to be calm and trained.
In the first phase of our art project, we will draw our ideas on paper.
My family is in a new phase of life because we just moved to a different town.
The moon looks different every night because it goes through different phases.

meanings: To pierce means to make a hole in something by pushing a sharp object through it, like when you use a needle to make a hole in fabric or when you poke a hole in a balloon.
examples: The needle can pierce the fabric to help me sew my shirt.
When the ice cream cone fell, the scoop pierced the ground.
I watched as the bird's beak pierced the fruit to get to the sweet juice.
The brave knight used his sword to pierce the dragon's tough scales.
When I threw the dart, it pierced the target right in the center.

meanings: To ask someone for something in a very serious way, like when you really want a toy or help with something important.
examples: I had to plead with my mom for an extra cookie after dinner.
My friend began to plead for a chance to play the new video game with us.
I will plead with my teacher to let us have a class party next week.
When the dog ran away, I had to plead with my dad to help me find him.
During the game, I plead with my teammate to pass the ball to me.

meanings: To jump or dive into water really quickly, like when you leap into a pool and make a big splash!
examples: I watched my dog plunge into the pool to fetch the ball.
During the swimming lesson, I took a deep breath and plunged into the water.
When the snow started falling, we couldn’t wait to plunge into the winter fun outside.
At the playground, I saw my friend plunge down the slide with a big smile.
We decided to plunge into the big pile of leaves and make a mess!

meanings: A portion is a piece or part of something bigger, like when you take one slice of cake from the whole cake to eat.
examples: I saved a portion of my birthday cake to eat later.
In art class, we painted a portion of the big mural together.
I only ate a small portion of my dinner because I wasn't very hungry.
During the game, each player got a portion of the candy as a prize.
My teacher gave us a portion of time to finish our reading assignment.

meanings: To jump suddenly and quickly to catch something, like a cat leaping to catch a toy or a bug.
examples: The cat will pounce on the toy mouse when it sees it move.
My puppy loves to pounce on the grass when we play fetch in the yard.
When I play tag with my friends, I try to pounce on them to make them it.
The frog will pounce on a fly to catch its dinner in the pond.
During our game of hide and seek, I had to pounce out from my hiding spot!

meanings: To do something over and over again so you can get better at it, like practicing for a soccer game or learning a new song on the piano.
examples: I will practice my spelling words every night to get better at them.
My soccer coach says we need to practice our passing skills to win the game.
If I want to play the piano well, I have to practice every day after school.
We can practice our dance moves together before the big performance next week.
She decided to practice drawing so she could make a beautiful picture for her mom.

meanings: Something that is very special and valuable to us, like a favorite toy or a treasured gift, that we take care of and love.
examples: My grandma gave me a precious necklace that has been in our family for many years.
The blue butterfly we saw in the garden was so precious and beautiful.
I keep my precious drawings in a special folder so they don’t get damaged.
My dog is precious to me because he always makes me feel happy and loved.
The moments we spend together as a family are precious and should always be cherished.

meanings: A precipice is a very tall and steep cliff where the ground drops off suddenly, like the edge of a giant rock that you should stay away from to be safe.
examples: The hiker stood at the edge of the precipice, looking down at the beautiful valley below.
During our nature walk, we saw a bird flying near the precipice of the tall mountain.
My brother was careful not to get too close to the precipice while he was exploring the cliffs.
The view from the precipice was amazing, and we all took pictures to remember it.
In the story, the hero climbed to the precipice to rescue his friend who was stuck on the edge.

meanings: To prefer means to like one thing more than another and choose it when you can. For example, if you prefer pizza, it means you would rather eat pizza than a hamburger.
examples: I prefer chocolate ice cream over vanilla because it tastes sweeter.
When playing soccer, I prefer to be the goalkeeper because I like making saves.
At the library, I prefer mystery books because they are exciting to read.
My brother prefers playing video games, but I like drawing and painting more.
During summer, I prefer going to the beach instead of staying home all day.

meanings: To get everything ready for something you plan to do, like packing your backpack for school or getting your clothes ready for a party.
examples: I need to prepare my backpack for school by packing my books and lunch.
Before the party starts, we will prepare the games and decorations in the backyard.
My mom and I prepare dinner together every Sunday, making our favorite spaghetti.
The coach wants us to prepare for the big soccer game by practicing our skills.
I will prepare my art supplies so I can start painting my picture after school.

meanings: Progress means getting better at something or moving closer to a goal, like when you practice a sport and improve your skills or when you learn to read harder books.
examples: I made progress in my reading by practicing every day after school.
Our soccer team is showing great progress as we learn new skills and play together.
When I practice my piano, I can see my progress with each song I learn.
My garden is starting to look nice, and I can see the progress of my plants growing.
We can track our progress in math by checking how many problems we get right each week.

meanings: A project is a fun task or activity you plan and work on, like making a craft, writing a story, or building something, to achieve a special goal.
examples: I am working on a science project about the life cycle of butterflies.
For art class, we are starting a big project to create a mural on the wall.
My teacher gave us a project to build a model of our favorite animal.
We are doing a group project to learn about different countries around the world.
At home, I have a project to plant flowers in the garden with my mom.

meanings: To prompt means to help someone remember to do something, like when a teacher reminds you to hand in your homework or when a friend encourages you to try a new game.
examples: The teacher used a picture to prompt us to start writing our stories.
My mom gave me a reminder to prompt me to finish my homework before dinner.
When I saw the rain, it prompted me to grab my umbrella and go outside.
The timer on my game will prompt me when it's time to take a break.
Seeing my friend smile can prompt me to share my toys and play together.

meanings: A prospect is something you hope will happen in the future, like getting a new pet or going to a fun place.
examples: The prospect of going to the amusement park excited all of my friends and me.
I like the prospect of having a sleepover this weekend with my best friend.
There is a good prospect that we will win the soccer game if we practice hard.
The prospect of getting a puppy makes my little brother jump for joy.
I think there's a bright prospect for us to earn stickers if we keep our classroom clean.

meanings: To prune means to cut away the dead or extra parts of a plant, like giving it a little haircut so it can grow better and look pretty!
examples: My dad helped me prune the bushes in our garden to make them look nice.
We learned how to prune plants in science class by cutting off the old leaves.
After we prune the trees, they will grow healthier and have more fruit.
I watched my grandma prune her flowers so they can bloom beautifully in spring.
When we prune the overgrown branches, our backyard will have more sunlight.

meanings: Quaint means something that is old-fashioned and charming, like a little cottage that looks special and different from the big, modern houses.
examples: The little bookstore in town is quaint, with its colorful shelves and cozy reading nooks.
My grandparents' house is quaint, filled with old pictures and furniture that tell many stories.
We found a quaint café that serves the best hot chocolate and has charming decorations.
The quaint garden behind my school has beautiful flowers and a tiny pond with fish.
I love visiting my aunt’s quaint cottage, where we can sit by the fireplace and tell stories.

meanings: A quarry is a place where people dig into the ground to find large stones or rocks that can be used to build things like houses, roads, and bridges.
examples: The workers at the quarry dig deep in the ground to find big stones.
We learned in class that a quarry is where people get rocks for buildings.
When we went hiking, we saw an old quarry filled with water and fish.
My dad took me to a quarry to show me where they get marble for countertops.
The kids built a pretend quarry in the sandbox and filled it with toy trucks.

meanings: To shake or move lightly, usually because you are feeling nervous or excited, like when you hold a puppy that makes you happy!
examples: The leaves began to quiver in the wind as the storm approached.
I could see my puppy's tail quiver with excitement when I came home.
As I stood on the edge of the diving board, my legs started to quiver with nerves.
When it was time for the big performance, I felt my hands quiver with excitement.
The little rabbit would quiver whenever it heard a loud noise in the garden.

meanings: A ramp is a slanted surface that helps you move from a lower place to a higher place, like walking up to a slide or pushing a wheelchair up to a door.
examples: The skateboarder zoomed up the ramp and did a cool trick in the skate park.
We used a ramp to help our toy cars go faster down the hill.
At the playground, the slide was really fun, but the ramp made it easy for everyone to climb up.
My dad built a ramp so our puppy could get into the car by himself.
During the science fair, I made a model with a ramp to show how gravity works.

meanings: To remember something from the past, like a fun day with friends or a favorite story you heard.
examples: I can recall the fun time we had at the beach last summer.
During the test, I had to recall what I studied about dinosaurs.
Can you recall where we put the puzzle pieces after we finished?
When I hear that song, I can easily recall my last birthday party.
My dog always seems to recall my voice, even when I call him from far away.

meanings: Something that happened not too long ago, like a birthday party you enjoyed or a movie you just watched.
examples: I read a recent book about dinosaurs that I really enjoyed.
My sister made a recent drawing of our dog that looks just like him.
We had a recent field trip to the science museum, and it was amazing!
I learned a recent math trick that helps me add numbers faster.
Our team won a recent soccer game, and everyone was so excited!

meanings: To recite means to say something out loud that you have memorized, like a poem or a story you can tell without looking at the words.
examples: In class, I had to recite a poem I learned about the stars.
During the school play, I will recite my lines on stage in front of everyone.
My little brother can recite the names of all the dinosaurs from memory.
We practiced every day so I could recite my speech for the science fair.
At home, I like to recite my favorite story to my pet cat before bedtime.

meanings: To recognize someone or something means to remember who they are or what they look like because you've seen them before, like spotting a friend in the playground or finding your favorite book on a she...
examples: I can recognize my favorite cartoon character when I see him on TV.
When I saw my old teacher at the store, I quickly recognized her smile.
If I hear the song we danced to at the school play, I will recognize it right away.
My dog always recognizes me when I come home from school.
At the zoo, I could recognize the different animals from the pictures in my book.

meanings: To tell someone that you think something is really good and that they should try it, like recommending a fun book or a tasty snack.
examples: I recommend reading this book because it has a really exciting adventure.
My teacher recommends we practice math every day to get better.
If you're looking for a fun game, I recommend playing tag with your friends.
I recommend visiting the zoo to see all the amazing animals.
My mom recommends using a planner to help me stay organized for school.

meanings: To get better after being sick, like when you have a cold and then feel healthy again.
examples: I hope my dog will recover quickly after his visit to the vet.
After being sick for a week, I was happy to recover and go back to school.
It took me a while to recover my lost toy from under the couch.
My sister is learning to recover her balance while riding her bike.
After a tough soccer game, we need time to recover and rest.

meanings: To make something smaller or use less of it, like turning off the lights to save energy or using a smaller plate for your food.
examples: We can reduce the amount of plastic we use by bringing our own bags to the store.
When we recycle, we help reduce the amount of trash that goes to the landfill.
To save water, we can reduce the time we spend in the shower each day.
Eating less candy can help reduce the chances of getting a stomach ache.
If we turn off the lights when we leave a room, we can reduce our electricity usage.

meanings: To make something better by fixing small parts or making little changes, like polishing a rock to make it shine or improving a drawing by adding details.
examples: I want to refine my drawing by adding more colors and details to make it look great.
Before the science fair, I will refine my project to make sure everything works perfectly.
My coach helps me refine my soccer skills so I can play better during the games.
We can refine our story by changing some words to make it more exciting for readers.
I will refine my dance moves to make my performance smoother and more fun to watch.

meanings: To get something back that you lost, like finding your favorite toy or making up with a friend after a fight.
examples: I lost my favorite toy, but I hope to regain it when I find it under my bed.
After my soccer team lost the game, we practiced hard to regain our winning skills.
When I got sick, I took medicine to help me regain my strength and feel better.
I accidentally broke my sister's drawing, but I will help her regain her smile by making her a new one.
My puppy ran away for a day, but I was so happy when I finally regained him at the park.

meanings: To say no to something you don't want, like when someone offers you a snack you don't like, and you choose not to take it.
examples: I had to reject the idea of playing outside because it was raining.
When I asked my friend to play a game, he decided to reject my invitation.
I will reject the candy because I want to eat a healthy snack instead.
The teacher had to reject the loud noise from the class so we could focus.
My dog will sometimes reject the new food if he doesn't like the taste.

meanings: To let something go or set it free, like when you open your hand to let a butterfly fly away.
examples: After school, I will release my pet turtle back into its pond.
During our science project, we learned how to release the air from a balloon.
When I finish my homework, I can release my stress by playing outside.
The teacher will release the students for lunch when the bell rings.
I helped my dad release the baby bird that fell from its nest.

meanings: To stop being strict and allow things to be easier, like when a teacher decides to give more time for a project.
examples: After a long talk, my teacher decided to relent and let us have extra recess time.
My mom said I could only have one cookie, but she finally relented and gave me two.
When the rain stopped, the coach chose to relent and let us play soccer outside.
At first, Dad didn’t want to watch a movie, but he relented and let us pick one together.
My sister was strict about sharing her toys, but she relented and let me play with her favorite doll.

meanings: To say something about what you notice or feel, like giving your opinion during a talk with friends.
examples: My teacher made a nice remark about my drawing in art class.
During lunch, Mia made a funny remark that made everyone laugh.
Dad's remark about my basketball skills made me feel proud.
After the game, Coach gave a remark about how well we played as a team.
I heard a remark from my sister about how pretty the flowers looked in the garden.

meanings: To replace something means to take it out and put something new in its place. For example, if you lose a favorite sock, you might get a new one that looks similar.
examples: I decided to replace my old bike with a shiny new one for my birthday.
When my favorite shirt got a hole, I had to replace it with a different color.
If my friend can't come to the party, I will replace her with another friend.
We need to replace the broken toy so we can play with it again.
The teacher will replace the missing books on the shelf for our class library.

meanings: To stand in for someone or something, like when a student talks for their class in a meeting or when a drawing shows what something is like.
examples: The flag represents our country and shows we are proud of where we live.
In art class, I made a drawing that represents my favorite animal, the elephant.
The team mascot represents our school spirit during games and cheers us on.
When we sing the national anthem, we represent all the people who love our country.
My drawing of a heart represents how much I love my family and friends.

meanings: To ask someone for something nicely, like when you say, "Can I have a cookie, please?
examples: I made a request to my teacher to have extra time for the math test.
My sister sent a request to borrow my favorite book for the weekend.
I will request a new game for my birthday this year.
After the movie, I will request some ice cream for dessert.
When I see a dog at the park, I can request to pet it from the owner.

meanings: To resist means to try really hard not to do something you don't want to do, like saying no to a cookie when you know you should eat a healthy snack instead.
examples: I tried to resist eating the whole cake, but it was too delicious.
When my brother teases me, I have to resist getting upset and stay calm.
During the game, I had to resist the urge to shout when I scored a point.
Even though it was hard, I wanted to resist the candy until after dinner.
My dog can resist chasing squirrels when I call him to come back.

meanings: To answer someone when they talk to you or ask you a question. For example, if a friend asks you what your favorite color is, you respond by telling them your favorite color.
examples: When the teacher asked a question, I raised my hand to respond.
My dog wags his tail to respond when I call his name.
After I shared my snack, my friend smiled to respond with thanks.
I always try to respond quickly when my mom asks for help.
During the game, I will respond to my teammate's signal by passing the ball.

meanings: To show or tell something that was hidden or not known before, like when you share a surprise with your friends.
examples: The magician will reveal his greatest trick at the school talent show.
When I opened the gift, it revealed a brand new skateboard inside.
The teacher will reveal the winner of the art contest on Friday.
My puppy likes to dig in the garden and sometimes reveals buried treasures.
The clues in the mystery book will reveal who the sneaky thief is.

meanings: To look at something again and make it better, like changing a story or homework before you give it to your teacher.
examples: I need to revise my story because I want to make it even better.
Before I turn in my homework, I will revise it to fix any mistakes.
My teacher asked us to revise our essays after reading her feedback.
When I draw pictures, I sometimes revise them to make them look nicer.
I will revise my plan for the school project to include more fun ideas.

meanings: To win a game or match by a very large score, making the other team or player feel like they cannot win anymore.
examples: Our soccer team had a rout against the other team and won by five goals.
In the game of chess, I managed to rout my opponent in just a few moves.
During the school competition, our class had a rout and won all the challenges easily.
The superheroes in the movie worked together to rout the villains and save the day.
At the science fair, my project was so impressive that it caused a rout among the other entries.

meanings: Scarce means that there is not a lot of something, making it hard to find or get. For example, if there are only a few toys left in a store, those toys are scarce.
examples: Fresh strawberries are scarce at the store during winter, so we might need to wait until summer to enjoy them.
In the game, special coins are scarce, and you have to search hard to find them.
When it snows, snowmen become scarce because everyone wants to build one right away.
During the school talent show, good seats are scarce, so we arrived early to get a good view.
Books about dinosaurs are scarce in our library, so I always check if they have more coming soon.

meanings: To scorch means to burn something on the outside, like when toast gets too dark because it was in the toaster too long.
examples: I accidentally left my toast in the toaster too long and it started to scorch.
The sun can scorch the grass if it doesn’t rain for a long time.
Be careful when you touch the grill; it can scorch your fingers if you’re not careful.
My mom said to watch the cookies so they don’t scorch in the oven.
After playing outside, my skin felt hot because the sun could scorch me.

meanings: A scoundrel is a person who is untrustworthy and often does mean things, like tricking others or breaking rules.
examples: The sneaky scoundrel took my lunch money and ran away before I could catch him.
In our game, the scoundrel always tries to cheat and steal extra points from everyone.
My dog is a little scoundrel; he always digs in the trash when I'm not looking.
The scoundrel in the story tricked the other animals to get their food for himself.
During the school play, the scoundrel pretended to be nice, but he was really up to no good.

meanings: To scurry means to move quickly and hurriedly with small, quick steps, like a squirrel running to gather nuts.
examples: The little mouse will scurry across the floor when it hears a loud noise.
During the fire drill, we had to scurry outside to the safe area quickly.
My dog loves to scurry after the ball when I throw it in the yard.
The kids began to scurry around the playground when they saw the bell ring for recess.
When it started to rain, the birds would scurry to find shelter under the trees.

meanings: To seize means to quickly grab or take hold of something, like when you snatch your favorite toy before someone else gets it.
examples: When the soccer ball rolled toward me, I decided to seize it before anyone else could.
I saw a butterfly land on a flower, so I wanted to seize the moment and take a picture.
During the game, I had to seize my chance to catch the flying frisbee.
My little brother tried to seize my toy, but I told him to ask first.
We must seize the opportunity to help our friends when they need it.

meanings: Being sensitive means you can easily notice your feelings and understand how others feel too, like when you see a friend is upset and want to cheer them up.
examples: My sister is very sensitive, so she often gets upset when someone teases her at school.
The dog is sensitive to loud noises, so he hides under the bed during thunderstorms.
When I see my friend looking sad, I try to be sensitive and ask if she’s okay.
My mom is sensitive about her cooking, so she loves when we tell her how tasty it is.
The teacher is sensitive to our feelings, so she helps us when we have a tough day.

meanings: Feeling a strong connection to something because it reminds you of happy times or special people from your past.
examples: My grandma is very sentimental about the old photo album filled with pictures of our family.
I feel sentimental when I look at my favorite stuffed animal from when I was a baby.
The movie made me sentimental because it reminded me of fun times I had with my friends.
My dad is sentimental about his baseball glove; he used it when he played in school.
I get sentimental when I listen to the song my mom used to sing to me at bedtime.

meanings: To keep things or people apart from each other, like when you put your crayons in different colors or sit on opposite sides of the room.
examples: I need to separate the red crayons from the blue ones in my art box.
During the game, we had to separate into two teams to play soccer.
My mom asked me to separate the laundry into dark and light clothes.
When we bake cookies, we separate the dough into small balls before cooking them.
I like to separate my books by color on the shelf in my room.

meanings: Very serious or strong, like a big storm that can be dangerous or when someone gets hurt.
examples: The storm last night was so severe that it knocked down many trees in our neighborhood.
My teacher said we need to be careful because the test will have severe questions that are really hard.
After the severe rain, the pond in the park was much fuller and the ducks were swimming everywhere.
When my brother didn't wear a jacket outside, he got a severe cold and had to stay home from school.
The coach warned us that if we didn't practice hard, our performance in the game could be severely affected.

meanings: Shallow means something that is not very deep, like a small pool of water where you can easily see the bottom.
examples: The puddle in our yard is very shallow, so I can splash my feet without getting wet.
My little brother likes to play in the shallow end of the pool where he can stand up easily.
We found some shallow holes in the sand where we could build small castles at the beach.
The stream behind our house is shallow, so we often catch tiny fish swimming in it.
During art class, we used shallow bowls to mix our paint colors without making a big mess.

meanings: Being shrewd means being smart and clever, like knowing the best way to solve a tricky problem or make a good choice.
examples: My shrewd little brother always knows the best way to win at board games.
The shrewd girl figured out the secret code in our scavenger hunt right away.
Dad made a shrewd choice when he bought the toy on sale instead of full price.
During the science project, Mia was shrewd and found a way to save time and effort.
The shrewd puppy learned how to open the door to get outside and play.

meanings: To shun someone means to stay away from them on purpose, like when you decide not to play with someone because they are not being nice to you.
examples: Some kids at school decided to shun the new student because he looked different.
After the argument, Sarah chose to shun her friend for a few days until they could talk.
During the game, I had to shun the players who were being unfair and not following the rules.
The dog would shun the rain and stay inside when it started pouring outside.
If you shun junk food, you will feel healthier and have more energy to play!

meanings: To do something really well and impress everyone, like when you give a great performance or make a beautiful drawing.
examples: The knight in the story had to slay the dragon to save the village.
In our video game, we work together to slay the monster and win the treasure.
My superhero toy can slay villains and protect the world from danger.
During the science project, we learned how plants can slay harmful insects naturally.
The brave princess decided to slay the evil sorcerer to bring peace to her kingdom.

meanings: Sole" means being the only one or the single one. For example, if you have the sole toy in a game, it means you are the only one who has that toy.
examples: I was the sole runner in the race who finished without getting tired.
She is the sole artist in our class who can draw such amazing pictures.
My dog is my sole friend who always waits for me when I come home.
He is the sole captain of our soccer team, and he leads us in every game.
The sole cookie left in the jar was my favorite chocolate chip one.

meanings: A source is the place where something comes from or begins. For example, a tree is a source of apples because it grows the apples we eat.
examples: The river is the main source of water for the plants in our garden.
In science class, we learned that the sun is the source of light for our planet.
My teacher is a great source of knowledge about animals and their habitats.
When we bake cookies, flour is the source of the dough that makes them soft.
The library is a wonderful source of books and stories to read after school.

meanings: Having a lot of space or room to move around freely, like a big, empty room or a large park where you can run and play.
examples: The new classroom is very spacious, so we can all move around easily during our projects.
My family's living room is spacious enough for a big couch and a table for games.
When we go camping, I love the spacious tent where we can all sleep together.
The playground has a spacious area where we can run, jump, and play games with friends.
My dog loves the spacious backyard where he can chase after his frisbee without bumping into anything.

meanings: Stingy means not wanting to share what you have, like toys or money, even when you have plenty. It's when someone has a lot but still keeps it all to themselves instead of sharing with friends.
examples: My brother is stingy with his candy and never wants to share with me.
In our group project, Jake was stingy and didn't want to let anyone use his markers.
Mom said it's stingy to keep all the cookies to himself when we have guests over.
Sometimes, being stingy can hurt your friend's feelings if you don't share your toys.
At the birthday party, Tim was stingy and only gave one piece of cake to each person.

meanings: Stout means being strong and thick, like a big, sturdy tree or a strong person who can lift heavy things.
examples: My stout dog can jump over the fence with ease.
The stout tree in our backyard provides plenty of shade on hot days.
During gym class, we lifted the stout weights to build our muscles.
The stout little boy was strong enough to carry his backpack all by himself.
We built a stout fort out of pillows and blankets in the living room.

meanings: To give something to a teacher or a grown-up so they can check it or decide what to do with it, like turning in your homework.
examples: I need to submit my homework to the teacher before the bell rings.
After finishing my drawing, I will submit it for the art contest.
My soccer team decided to submit our best photos for the yearbook.
If you want to join the club, you have to submit an application form.
I will submit my ideas for the science project to my group today.

meanings: Having enough of something to do what you need, like having sufficient snacks for a party means you have enough for all your friends to enjoy.
examples: I had sufficient time to finish my homework before dinner.
The teacher said we have sufficient supplies for our art project.
My dad made a sufficient amount of cookies for the bake sale.
There was sufficient light in the room to read my book.
We had sufficient water during our hike to stay hydrated.

meanings: Sullen means feeling sad and not wanting to talk or smile, like when someone is upset and stays quiet instead of joining in on fun.
examples: Lily looked sullen after losing the game, sitting quietly while her friends celebrated.
When Max didn't get the toy he wanted, he became sullen and crossed his arms.
The weather was sullen and rainy, making everyone feel a little sad and sleepy.
After their argument, Jake sat alone with a sullen expression on his face.
The dog seemed sullen when his owner left for the day, lying down with a sad look.

meanings: To summon someone means to call them to come to you, like when you wave to a friend to join you or when a teacher asks a student to come up front.
examples: The teacher will summon all the students to the assembly in the gym.
I can summon my dog by calling his name when it's time for a walk.
When it starts to rain, we can summon our umbrellas from the closet.
My mom can summon my dad when she needs help cooking dinner.
During the game, I will summon my friends to join me on the playground.

meanings: The surface is the outside part of something that you can see and feel, like the top of a table or the skin of a fruit.
examples: The surface of the water sparkled in the sunlight as we rowed our boat.
I drew a picture on the surface of my notebook during art class.
The ice on the pond was smooth and shiny on the surface.
We found colorful leaves on the surface of the ground during our nature walk.
The table's surface was covered with crayons and paper after our craft project.

meanings: To surround something means to be all around it, like when you and your friends make a circle around a big tree or a toy.
examples: The trees surround the playground, making it a cozy spot for us to play.
My dog loves to run around the yard, where flowers surround his favorite spot.
During the picnic, our friends surround the blanket to enjoy lunch together.
The mountains surround our town, creating a beautiful view every day.
I like to build forts with my friends, and we surround ourselves with pillows and blankets.

meanings: To think that someone might have done something wrong, like when you wonder if a friend took your toy without asking.
examples: I suspect that my brother took my favorite toy when I wasn't looking.
When my ice cream disappeared, I began to suspect my sneaky little sister.
I suspect that it might rain today because the sky is very dark.
After hearing the loud noise, I suspect there might be a raccoon in the trash.
I suspect my dog is hiding because he knows he did something wrong.

meanings: A symbol is a picture or sign that represents something else, like a heart that means love or a peace sign that means kindness.
examples: A heart is a symbol of love that people often draw on cards for special occasions.
In our school, the eagle is a symbol of courage and strength for our sports teams.
The peace sign is a symbol that shows we want everyone to live happily without fighting.
In science class, we learned that a tree can be a symbol of life and growth.
The rainbow is a beautiful symbol of hope after a stormy day.

meanings: A symptom is a sign that shows something might be wrong with our body or feelings, like having a fever or a tummy ache when we’re sick.
examples: If you have a fever, that is a symptom that you might be getting sick.
A headache can be a symptom of not drinking enough water during the hot day.
When my dog started coughing, it was a symptom that he needed to see the vet.
Feeling very tired can be a symptom that you need more sleep at night.
If you feel a tickle in your throat, that might be a symptom of a cold coming on.

meanings: A talon is a sharp claw that birds, like eagles and hawks, use to catch and hold their food, just like how we use our hands to grab things.
examples: The eagle used its sharp talon to catch a fish swimming in the river.
We saw a big owl at the nature center, and it had powerful talons.
When the hawk landed on the tree, we could see its strong talon gripping the branch.
My dad taught me that a lion uses its talon-like claws to hold onto its prey.
In art class, we painted pictures of birds with long wings and sharp talons.

meanings: Temporary means something that is not permanent and will only last for a short time. For example, a raincoat is temporary because you only wear it when it’s raining, not all day.
examples: The sign on the playground said it was closed for temporary repairs.
We set up a temporary tent in the backyard for our camping night.
My grandma is staying with us for a temporary visit during the holidays.
The ice cream truck parked on our street for a temporary time before driving away.
We used a temporary bandage on my cut until we could get a better one.

meanings: Terror is a very strong feeling of fear, like when you see something really scary or when you feel worried about something dangerous.
examples: The sudden loud noise made me feel a wave of terror as I hid under my bed.
When I saw the scary movie, I felt terror wash over me during the spooky scenes.
My little brother screamed in terror when he saw a giant spider in his room.
During the thunderstorm, I felt a bit of terror as the lightning flashed outside.
The haunted house at the fair filled me with terror, but I was brave and went inside anyway.

meanings: Threadbare means something, like a piece of clothing or a blanket, that is very old and has holes or thin spots because it has been used a lot.
examples: My favorite sweater is threadbare because I've worn it every winter for years.
The threadbare blanket on the couch is so soft and cozy, even if it has some holes.
After many adventures, my teddy bear's fur is threadbare and needs a little stitching.
The threadbare carpet in the classroom has seen many happy feet walking on it.
My dad's old jeans are threadbare, but he says they are his most comfortable pair.

meanings: A threat is when someone says or does something that makes you feel scared because it seems like they might hurt you or someone else.
examples: The dark clouds in the sky were a threat of a big storm coming.
When my friend said she would tell the teacher, it felt like a threat to me.
The broken swing at the playground is a threat to anyone who wants to play on it.
He made a threat to take my toy if I didn't share, which made me feel scared.
In the forest, we learned that fire can be a threat to the animals living there.

meanings: To torment means to bother or hurt someone on purpose, making them feel sad or upset, like when someone teases a friend too much and it hurts their feelings.
examples: The bully would torment the younger kids during recess by teasing them and calling them names.
It can torment a puppy when it hears loud thunder and doesn't know what to do.
Watching my friend lose his favorite game can torment me because I want him to win.
Sometimes, homework can torment me when it feels too hard and takes a long time to finish.
When my sister hides my toys, it can really torment me until I find them again.

meanings: A tour is a fun trip where you go to see interesting places and learn about them, usually with a guide who tells you stories and facts.
examples: We went on a school tour of the science museum to learn about dinosaurs and space.
My family took a tour of the zoo to see all the different animals and their habitats.
During summer camp, we had a nature tour where we learned about plants and animals in the forest.
The tour of the city showed us famous landmarks and fun places to visit with our friends.
Our teacher organized a tour of the library to help us find great books to read.

meanings: A tower is a tall, narrow building that reaches high into the sky, like a big tree or the tallest part of a playground slide. You can find towers in cities, where they help people see far away from th...
examples: The tall tower in the park has a slide that goes all the way to the ground.
We built a tower of blocks that reached almost to the ceiling in our classroom.
The lighthouse is a special tower that helps boats find their way to the shore.
During the game, we tried to make a tower out of cards without it falling down.
My dad took a picture of me standing next to the tall tower at the amusement park.

meanings: A tradition is a special way of doing things that families or groups have shared for a long time, like celebrating holidays or telling stories.
examples: Every year, my family has a tradition of making cookies together for the holidays.
At school, we have a tradition of celebrating our birthdays with a special song.
My friends and I started a tradition of playing soccer every Saturday morning.
In my family, it is a tradition to tell stories around the campfire during summer vacation.
Every spring, we have a tradition of planting flowers in the garden together.

meanings: Tragic means something that is very sad and makes people feel really upset, like when a character in a story gets hurt or when something bad happens to someone we care about.
examples: It was tragic when my favorite toy broke right before my birthday party.
The movie had a tragic ending that made everyone in the theater cry.
Losing my pet fish was a tragic moment that made me feel very sad.
The tragic story of the lost puppy made us all want to help find it.
When my friend moved away, it felt like a tragic loss for our whole class.

meanings: A trio is a group of three people or things, like three friends playing together or a band with three musicians.
examples: My mom, dad, and I make a happy trio when we go on family outings.
In music class, our trio played a beautiful song with three different instruments.
At the playground, I saw a trio of friends swinging together on the swings.
For the science project, we formed a trio to create a cool volcano model.
The three puppies in the park made an adorable trio that everyone wanted to pet.

meanings: A trophy is a shiny prize you get when you win a game or competition, like a sports match or a contest. It shows everyone you worked hard and did something really great!
examples: I won a trophy for being the best player on my soccer team this year.
My sister has a big trophy for winning first place in the spelling bee contest.
We took a picture with the trophy after our basketball team won the championship.
Every time I see the trophy on the shelf, it reminds me of my hard work.
Dad gave me a trophy for completing my science project all by myself.

meanings: To trudge means to walk slowly and with a lot of effort, like when you're really tired or when you have to walk through thick mud.
examples: After a long hike, we had to trudge up the steep hill to get back to the car.
When it started to rain, we had to trudge through the muddy puddles to reach home.
I felt tired and had to trudge slowly to my classroom after gym class.
The dog began to trudge along the path, looking for its favorite stick to play with.
On our way to the playground, we had to trudge through the thick snow in our boots.

meanings: Typical" means something that is normal or happens often for a certain group, like how most schools have classes or how many kids like to play outside.
examples: A typical day at school starts with the morning bell ringing at eight o'clock.
During a typical soccer game, we run, kick, and cheer for our team.
My dog has a typical routine of eating, playing, and napping all day long.
On a typical weekend, my family likes to go hiking and have a picnic.
It's typical for my brother to play video games after he finishes his homework.

meanings: Feeling worried or nervous about something that might happen, like when you have to speak in front of the class and you're not sure if you'll do well.
examples: I felt uneasy when I had to speak in front of the whole class.
My dog seemed uneasy during the loud thunderstorm last night.
I felt uneasy when I couldn't find my favorite toy in my room.
When I tried out for the soccer team, I felt a little uneasy about my skills.
Seeing the big spider in the corner made me feel uneasy and I wanted to leave the room.

meanings: To use something in a smart way to help you do something better. For example, you can utilize your toys to make a fun game.
examples: We can utilize our crayons to create beautiful pictures in art class.
The teacher asked us to utilize our books to find information for the project.
My dad utilizes old boxes to build cool forts in the living room.
During the game, we utilize teamwork to score points together.
I like to utilize my free time to read fun stories or play outside.

meanings: To say something clearly and completely, like when you speak your thoughts or feelings out loud.
examples: I couldn't utter a word when I saw the surprise party my friends planned for me.
During the class discussion, Mia was brave enough to utter her thoughts about the story we read.
When the teacher asked a question, I was too shy to utter my answer in front of everyone.
In the movie, the hero had to utter a special phrase to unlock the secret door.
The puppy began to utter soft barks when it wanted to play with me.

meanings: Someone who is vain cares a lot about how they look and thinks they are better or prettier than other people. They spend a lot of time trying to look good and want others to notice them.
examples: Jake was so vain that he looked in the mirror three times before leaving for school.
Lily was vain about her new dress and wanted everyone to notice how pretty it was.
During the game, Sam acted vain because he thought he could score all the points by himself.
My dog seems vain when he poses for pictures, always turning his head to look his best.
Ella was vain about her drawing and wanted everyone to say it was the best in the class.

meanings: Being brave and strong, especially when you have to face something scary or difficult, like helping a friend or trying a new sport.
examples: The valiant knight fought bravely to protect the kingdom from the dragon.
When the team was losing, our valiant captain encouraged us to keep trying our best.
She made a valiant effort to climb the tall tree, even though it was a bit scary.
The valiant puppy jumped into the water to save the little boy's toy boat.
During the school play, the valiant hero stood up to the giant and saved the day.

meanings: To change or be different in some way, like how the shapes of clouds can vary, with some looking like animals and others like castles.
examples: The colors of the flowers in the garden can vary depending on the season.
My teacher said the math problems can vary in difficulty, so some are easier than others.
The shapes of the clouds in the sky can vary, making them look like animals or castles.
The flavors of ice cream can vary, with choices like chocolate, strawberry, and mint.
During our game, the rules can vary each time we play to keep it exciting.

meanings: Very large, like a big ocean or a giant desert, where you can see a lot of space around you.
examples: The ocean is vast and filled with many different kinds of fish and sea creatures.
Our school library has a vast collection of books about dinosaurs and space.
The sky looked vast and blue as we watched the birds fly high above us.
My dad's garden is vast, with flowers and vegetables growing everywhere you look.
During the camping trip, we saw a vast forest that seemed to go on forever.

meanings: To try something new and exciting, even if it feels a little scary or uncertain.
examples: I decided to venture into the forest to explore and see what animals I could find.
My friends and I will venture to the top of the hill to see the beautiful sunset.
It was a big venture to try out for the school play, but I wanted to give it a shot.
We can venture to the lake to go fishing and maybe catch some big fish!
I felt nervous, but I wanted to venture out and ride my bike without training wheels.

meanings: A victim is a person who gets hurt or is treated unfairly by someone else, like when someone is bullied or when there is an accident.
examples: When the bully took his lunch, he felt like a victim of unfairness.
In the game of tag, the person who gets caught becomes the victim until they are freed.
After the storm, the tree fell, and the house became a victim of the strong winds.
When my brother accidentally broke my toy, I felt like a victim of his clumsiness.
In the story, the hero helps the victim of the dragon’s fire to feel safe again.

meanings: Vision is the ability to see things around you, like your family and pets, and also to imagine what you want to do or be when you grow up, like a superhero or a scientist.
examples: I have a vision of becoming an astronaut and exploring space one day.
During art class, I used my vision to imagine a colorful world filled with friendly monsters.
Our teacher asked us to share our vision for the school garden we want to create.
With a little vision, we can think of new games to play during recess.
I closed my eyes and used my vision to picture my dream treehouse in the backyard.

meanings: To waft means to move gently through the air, like the sweet smell of flowers floating to your nose or a soft breeze blowing through the trees.
examples: The sweet smell of cookies began to waft through the house as they baked in the oven.
As we walked through the garden, the scent of flowers would waft gently in the air.
When the teacher opened the window, a cool breeze wafted into the classroom.
The smoke from the campfire started to waft up into the night sky.
I could smell the popcorn wafting from the kitchen while I watched a movie with my family.

meanings: To wander means to walk around without a specific place to go, like when you explore a park or a new neighborhood just to see what you can discover.
examples: I like to wander through the garden and look at all the colorful flowers.
During our field trip, we got to wander around the zoo and see all the animals.
On sunny days, my dog loves to wander in the park and chase after butterflies.
When I finish my homework, I like to wander around the house and find something fun to do.
Sometimes, I wander around the playground to see what games my friends are playing.

meanings: When something is widespread, it means it is found in many places or used by many people. For example, if a toy is widespread, lots of kids all over the world have it and are playing with it!
examples: The new video game became widespread among my friends at school, and everyone wanted to play it.
After the big storm, there was widespread damage to the trees in our neighborhood.
The book series about wizards is widespread in our library, and many kids love to read it.
When spring arrives, the flowers bloom in a widespread way, making the park look colorful.
The idea of having a school pet became widespread, and many kids wanted to help take care of it.

meanings: To yield means to give or produce something, like when a tree gives us apples or when you share your toys with a friend.
examples: The farmer hopes his hard work will yield a big harvest of apples this year.
If we water the plants every day, they will yield beautiful flowers soon.
Our science project should yield interesting results if we follow the steps carefully.
The garden can yield fresh vegetables that we can eat for dinner.
Working together on the team will yield better results in our game.
